children.name: buy
children.definition: to pay money for something so that you can own it:
examples: ▪ I bought a new dress today at Macy’s.
▪ John makes his living buying and selling used cars.
▪ The painting was bought by a museum in New York.
buy somebody something
▪ Keith was going to buy me a ring, but now he says he wants to buy me a watch instead.
buy something for somebody
▪ If you don’t have enough money for the pen, I’ll buy it for you.
buy something from somebody
▪ I wouldn’t buy anything from him - I don’t trust him.
buy something for $10/£200 etc
▪ The ranch, which was originally bought for $20,000, is now valued at over $2 million.
buyverbbought,boughtPAY FOR mua
[ I or T ] to get something by paying money for it
_ [ + two objects ]He bought his mother some flowers /He bought some flowersforhis mother.
_I bought my camerafrom/informaloffa friend of mine.

children.name: get
children.definition: /get/  especiallyspokento buy something, especiallyordinarythings such as food, clothes, or thingsfor your house:
examples: ▪ Let me get the drinks. It’s my turn to pay.
▪ Did you remember to get the bread?

children.name: get somebody something
examples: ▪ Guess what he got her for her birthday - an iron!

children.name: get something for somebody
examples: ▪ I’m going to get one of those video games for Hillary.

children.name: get something for £20/$50 etc
examples: ▪ What do you think of this leather jacket? I got it for $40 on sale.

children.name: purchase
children.definition: to buy something- used in business and legal contracts:
examples: ▪ Foreign investors are not permitted to purchase land.
▪ If this product does not give complete satisfaction, please return it to the manufacturer stating when and where it was purchased.
purchase[uncountable noun]purchase of
▪ The loan was supposed to be used for the purchase of a house.
purchase st with st
▪ She perchased her first house with the money
purchaseverb[ T ]formal mua, tậu
to buy
She purchased her first housewiththe money. bằngtiền

children.name: snap up
children.definition: to buy somethingimmediately, especially because it is verycheapor youwantit very much, and you are worried that someone else might buy it first:
examples: chộp lấy
snap up something
▪ Readers have snapped up nearly 200,000 copies of the book.
▪ The best bargains tend to be snapped up immediately.
snap something up
▪ If you see one for under $100, snap it up!

children.name: splash out on sth
children.definition: splash out onBritish splurge (on something)American   to buy something you want such as anexpensivemeal, dress etc, which you would not usually buy because it is too expensive:
examples: phung phí tiền ...
▪ We splashed out on a bottle of champagne to celebrate her promotion.
▪ Let’s splurge and have the steak.

children.name: pick up
children.definition: to buy something that you have foundby chance, especially something that is unusuallycheap:
examples: kiếm được
pick up something
▪ He’s hoping to pick up a few bargains at the sales.
▪ It’s just a little thing I picked up when I was in Kathmandu.
pick something up
▪ That picture? Oh, I picked it up last week at a little shop downtown.

children.name: acquire
children.definition: to become the owner of something such as land, a company, or a valuable object:
examples: giành lại, chiếm
▪ In 1998 the business was acquired by a Dutch company.
▪ The statue was acquired at great expense by the City Corporation.
▪ Robinson spent $20 million to acquire the symphony hall.
acquisition/ˌækwɪˈzɪʃən, ˌækwəˈzɪʃən/ [uncountable noun]
acquisition of
▪ The National Gallery has set aside £10 million for the acquisition of the painting.

children.name: go to shop to buy sth
go shopping
children.definition: to go to shops to look at and buy things:
examples: ▪ Let’s meet in town. We can have lunch and go shopping.
▪ I’m going shopping now. Do you want anything?

children.name: go to the shops U
children.definition: go to the shopsBritishgo to the storeAmerican   to go out to the local shop or shops in order to buy something, especially the things that you needregularlysuch as food:

children.name: ▪ ‘Where’s Julie?’ ‘She’s gone to the shops.’
examples: ▪ If you go to the store, could you get some milk?
▪ Mr Parker, my next-door neighbour, is getting old and I sometimes go to the shops for him.

children.name: do the shopping
children.definition: to go to shops in order to buy the things that you needregularlysuch as food:
examples: ▪ On Saturdays we usually do the shopping and clean the house.
▪ She sent her husband out to do the week’s shopping.

children.name: do my/your etc shopping
examples: ▪ I did all my shopping yesterday.

children.name: grocery shoppingAmerican shopping for food
examples: ▪ We need to go grocery shopping - do you have the check book?

children.name: shop
children.definition: toregularlyuse aparticularshop, especially to buy things that you need regularly such as food:
examples: shop at/in
▪ I usually shop at Safeway. It’s just around the corner from my house.
▪ When she moved here, she had never shopped in a supermarket before.
shopverb-pp-BUY THINGS
[ I ] to buythings in shopsmua hàng
_I like to shopatHarrods for clothes.
_If I'm just shoppingforfood, I tend to go to the local supermarket.

children.name: shop around
children.definition: to go toseveraldifferent shopscomparinggoods and theirpricesbefore deciding which ones to buy:
examples: ▪ If you shop around you could probably get the camera a lot cheaper.
shop around for
▪ I spent a couple of weeks shopping around for the lowest insurance rates.
shop aroundphrasal verb
to comparethe price and quality of the same or a similar
object in different shops before you decide which one to buy
_When you're buying a flight, you should always shop around for the best deal.
( .. ban nen di dao cac cua hang cho su thoa thuan tot nhat )

children.name: window shopping
children.definition: when you look at things in shop windows without intending to buy anything:

children.name: đi bát phố
examples: ▪ We spent the morning window shopping at all the antique stores.

children.name: to look at a lot of things you might buy, read, etc
look around
children.definition: lookaround to walk around a shop or market or a place wheretouristsgo, looking at a lot of different things: xem chung quanh
examples: He makes a list of what he needs and then walks into the store and buys it, without looking around at all.

children.name: browse
children.definition: to spend time looking at things in ashop, especiallybooksorrecords, without intending to buy anything: xem qua
examples: Armando spent the afternoon browsing in Camden market.

children.name: browse through
examples: He found Jill in the gallery shop silently browsing through some books.

children.name: I’m just looking
children.definition: say this to tell sb who works in a shop that you are only looking at things, and you do not intend to buy anything just now: tôi chỉ xem chút thôi
examples: ‘Can I help you?’ ‘No thanks, I’m just looking.’

children.name: window-shopping
children.definition: the activity of looking at goods inshopwindowswithout intending to buy anything: dạo phố xem đồ
examples: We didn’t have any money but we enjoyed window-shopping in Fifth Avenue.

children.name: go window-shopping
examples: Sometimes I go window-shopping after work.

children.name: take a look around
children.definition: take/ have a look around to walk around a shop or market or a place wheretouristsgo, looking at a lot of different things: xem chung quanh
examples: I just want to take a quick look around and see if there’s anything I want.
You’re welcome to have a look around. We have a wide range of sportswear.

children.name: send out for
children.definition: /order out forUS  to ask a restaurant or a food shop to deliver food to you at home or work: yêu cầu giao hàng
examples: During the meeting we sent out for some coffee.
I don’t feel like cooking tonight. Let’s order out for a pizza.

children.name: order sth in
children.definition: ordersthinphrasal verb đặt cái gì tại nhà

children.name: to order foodthat is ready to eat to be brought to your home or to the place where you work
examples: _I think I'll stay home tonight, order in a pizza and watch a video.

children.name: order
children.definition: nounREQUEST sự đặt hàng

children.name: order
children.definition: to ask for something you are going to pay for- use this about asking for food or drink in restaurants, or asking companies to send you goods:
examples: order[countable noun] đơn đặt hàng
▪ I’m very sorry, but we seem to have lost your order.
orderverbREQUEST gọi (món ăn, thức uống...),
[ I or T ] to ask for something to be made, supplied ordelivered, especially in a restaurant or shop
_I ordered some pasta and a mixed salad.
_[ + two objects ]There are no shirts left in this
size but we could order oneforyou/order you one.

children.name: gọi món ăn
examples: ▪ Would you like to order a drink before dinner?
▪ We had ordered a pale blue armchair but the one that was delivered was dark green.
▪ I’m afraid we don’t have that book in stock, but we can order it for you.

children.name: place an order
children.definition: ordernounREQUEST sự đặt hàng
examples: [ C ]a requestto make, supply ordeliverfood or goods
_"Can Itakeyour order now?" said the waiter.
_I would like toplace(= make) an order for a large pine table.
( toi muon lam mot don dat hang cho mot ban go thong )
order formnoun[ C ] mẫu in sẵn để khách hàng đặt hàng điền vào; đơn đặt hàng
a printedform which a customer uses to request goods or a service
ordernounREQUEST hàng được đặt
[ C ] a product or a mealwhich has been requested by a customer
_The shop phoned to say your order has come in.

children.name: order
children.definition: nounREQUEST hàng được đặt

children.name: order form
children.definition: noun mẫu in sẵn để khách hàng đặt hàng điền vào; đơn đặt hàng
examples: a printedform which a customer uses to request goods or a service

children.name: be on order
children.definition: ( da dat roi nhung chua nhan duoc )

children.name: If something is on order, you have requested it but have not yet received it
examples: _The new drilling equipment has been on order for several weeks.

children.name: to buy a lot of sth
buy a lot of
children.definition: /lots of
examples: ▪ You’ve been buying a lot of clothes recently. Have you decided to change your image?
▪ We’ve bought lots of food and drink, so it should be a really good party.

children.name: stock up
children.definition: to buy alargequantityof something you useregularlybecause you may not be able to buy it later, or because you are planning to use more of it than usual:

children.name: mua hàng ( nhiều để dự trữ )
examples: ▪ The supermarkets are full of people stocking up for the New Year’s holiday.
▪ We might as well stock up while we’re here - it’ll save us having to come back.

children.name: stock up on
examples: ▪ We always stock up on cheap cigarettes when we go to Holland.

children.name: buy (sth) in bulk C1
children.definition: buy (something) in bulk  to buy a large quantity of something, especiallybecause it is cheaper to buy a lot of it at one time:

children.name: mua số lượng lớn
examples: ▪ We always buy in bulk. It is so much more economical.
▪ Today more shoppers are using coupons and buying items in bulk.

children.name: bulk buyingbuying goods in large quantities
examples: ▪ Bulk buying has enabled the company to cut costs.

children.name: wholesale
children.definition: if you buy something wholesale, you buy a large quantity of it directly from the company that makes it:
examples: wholesale[adjective]
▪ The shopkeeper buys his fruit and vegetables at wholesale prices.

children.name: ( mua ) sỉ
examples: ▪ Mark buys the earrings wholesale and then sells them for a profit.
▪ Let’s see if we can get them wholesale and save ourselves a few dollars.

children.name: buy up
children.definition: to quickly buy all of something such as land, tickets, food etc, when there is only a limited amount available:
examples: mua sạch, mua hết
buy up something
▪ In the last five years development agencies have bought up almost all the land in the area.
buy something up
▪ There weren’t any good seats left for the game - some big company had bought them all up.

children.name: buy in
children.definition: British to buy enough of something to last for a long time, for example because it may be difficult to buy later:
examples: mua tích trữ
buy in something
▪ People had to buy in candles during the electricity strike.
buy something in
▪ Villagers join together to buy enough food in to last throughout the winter.

children.name: import
children.definition: to buy goods from another country to be sold, used etc in your country, especially in large quantities:
examples: nhập khẩu
▪ The United States has to import some of its oil.import something from something
▪ Most of the wines served in this restaurant are imported from France.
imports/ˈɪmpɔːʳts/ [plural noun]hàng nhập
▪ In 1999 our imports goods that were imported greatly exceeded exports.
importverb[ T ]nhập, nhập khẩu
to buy or bring in products from another country
_We import a large number of carsfromJapan.

children.name: purchasing power
children.definition: noun sức mua

children.name: A person's purchasing power is their ability to buy goods
examples: _The purchasing powerofpeople living on investmentincome has fallen as interest rates have gone down.

children.name: shopping
children.definition: noun sự đi mua hàng

children.name: the activityof buying things from shops
examples: _The store is open for late night shopping on Wednesdays.
_I'mgoingshopping this afternoon.
_My granddaughterdoesmy weekly shopping for me.

children.name: brand loyalty
children.definition: nounsự gắn bó với nhãn hiệu; sự trung thành với nhãn hiệu

children.name: the habit always to buy a product with the same name, made by the same company
examples: _All manufacturers want to encourage brand loyalty to their own products.

children.name: purchase
children.definition: nounformalBUYING vật mua được, vật tậu được

children.name: purchase
children.definition: nounformalBUYING sự mua

children.name: import
children.definition: nounBRINGING IN hàng nhập, hàng nhập khẩu
examples: [ C ] goodsbought by one country from another
_restrictions on foreign imports ( han che hang nhap khau nuoc ngoai )

children.name: import /importation
children.definition: importnounBRINGING IN sự nhập, sự nhập khẩu
examples: [ U ] (alsoimportation)the actionof bringing goods or fashions into a country
_the illegal importation of drugs
_an import licence ( mot su cho fep nhap khau )
_import duties ( thue nhap khau )

children.name: on approval
children.definition: được bán với điều kiện khách không vừa ý thì cứ trả lại
examples: If you buysomethingon approval, you can return it without payment if it is not satisfactory.
